scenes.summary: Dorian spends the early morning in seclusion, tormented by a wild terror of death and haunted by the memory of his crime. His imagination transforms trivial sounds into ominous threats and the image of a sailor appears through the mist on the window. When Lord Henry finally arrives at six o’clock, he finds Dorian overcome with grief and inner turmoil.

characters: Other shooting party members (including beaters and the head-keeper)
scenes.location: Extensive grounds around Selby Royal – beginning in the garden and moving to the park and pine-wood shooting area
scenes.summary: Renewed by the clear, pine-scented winter morning, Dorian departs the house with the Duchess and joins a shooting party. In the crisp outdoors, he marvels at the landscape, and engages casually with Sir Geoffrey Clouston. During the party, a hare darts from the undergrowth prompting Sir Geoffrey to shoot; however, when Dorian pleads for the creature’s life, the gun is discharged mistakenly, and cries of pain herald a tragic accident: a man is inadvertently struck.

scenes.location: Shooting grounds leading back to the house, including a wooded thicket and the terrace
scenes.summary: Following the mishap on the shooting ground, a heated discussion ensues. Lord Henry, somewhat dismissively, suggests calling off the remainder of the shoot while philosophizing about omens and fate. Dorian, troubled by premonitions of disaster and the ominous accident, exchanges bitter and reflective comments with Lord Henry. A gardener then appears bearing a letter from the Duchess, leading to light banter on character and scandal as the group heads back.

scenes.location: Inside Dorian’s private quarters at Selby Royal
scenes.summary: Back in the confines of his own room, Dorian is overwhelmed by the terror and the burden of death’s proximity. Determining that life at Selby Royal is ill-omened, he orders his belongings to be packed for departure and writes a note to Lord Henry. Before leaving, he is visited by the head-keeper, who reports details of the morning’s accident, including the identification of the victim as a sailor—a revelation that unsettles Dorian deeply.

scenes.location: The long avenue and the Home Farm stables
scenes.summary: Driven by a mix of anxious hope and dread, Dorian hastily rides his mare down the avenue towards the Home Farm to inspect the body of the accident victim. Amid spectral, rushing landscapes, he reaches the stables where, after a tense moment of hesitation and with the aid of a servant, he uncovers the corpse. To his astonishment and relief, the dead body is identified as James Vane—the sailor whose threat once haunted him—thus, in a peculiar twist, affirming his safety from retribution.
